text: “I’ll try to change fate.” I answer a little hastily, but the moment the words leave my mouth, I realize they carry far more weight than I expected.
Alicia smiles faintly. The expression is gentle, but it doesn’t reach her eyes. “Many people say that.”
She slowly swirls her glass, the amber liquid catching the firelight as it ripples in circles.
“But fate never listens to persuasion. You think you’re changing it, yet you’re only walking a little farther along the path it already laid out.”
“What about you?” I ask. “Do you believe in fate, or are you fighting against it?”
Her hand pauses at the rim of the glass, her gaze settling into the glow of the fire. “I once believed I could win.”
The hearth flame leaps suddenly, a spark landing on her sleeve before she brushes it away. In that fleeting moment, I glimpse the shadow in her eyes—not fear, but exhaustion.
“Fate isn’t a die,” she says quietly. “It won’t change its number just because you will it to.”
She falls silent for a moment, then gives a faint smile. “Perhaps. But if I had the choice, I would rather not have tried at all.”
The smile is brief and fragile, as if concealing a wound too deep to name. Firelight flickers in her eyes, and in that shifting glow, even the air feels colder.
